selected_quotes: Heterofullerene-based biomimetic alpha-carbonic anhydrase analogues, Dr. P. A. Deshpande M. Verma

citation.abstract: Biomimetic CO<sub>2</sub> hydration activity of Ru/Rh-doped fullerenes was revealed by density functional theory calculations. Mechanism of CO<sub>2</sub> hydration on the proposed heterofullerenes followed the mechanistic action of α-carbonic anhydrases. The mechanism of the reaction consisted of adsorption and de-protonation of H<sub>2</sub>O, CO<sub>2</sub> interaction with hydroxyl groups, CO<sub>2</sub> bending, and proton transfer to give product HCO<sup>-</sup><sub>3</sub>. Free energy landscapes for the reaction showed the catalysts to be active for the reaction. H<sub>2</sub>O adsorption over the catalysts was exergonic while CO<sub>2</sub> adsorption over the catalyst-OH complex was observed to be an endergonic process. Intramolecular proton transfer resulting in the final product, HCO<sup>-</sup><sub>3</sub>, was found to be the rate limiting step for the reaction over C<sub>56</sub>N<sub>3</sub>M (M = Ru/Rh) while H<sub>2</sub>O dissociation was found to be the rate limiting step for the reaction over C<sub>59</sub>M (M = Ru/Rh). C<sub>56</sub>N<sub>3</sub>M catalysts were found to be superior to C<sub>59</sub>M catalysts for biomimetic CO<sub>2</sub> hydration, as signified by the free energy landscapes and energy requirements.

publisher_subjects.name: Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, Particle And Plasma Physics

citation.title: Computational design of novel heterofullerene-based biomimetic α-carbonic anhydrase analogues
